comments.author: Fearless Kitchen
comments.content: This is a really interesting risotto dish.  Using the liquid from the roasting tomatoes is an interesting touch, it not only keeps costs down but really enhances the tomato flavor (as you said.)

comments.author: Christel
comments.content:
To: Photographer

Are these 'knobs' of butter I see among the plate?
*high five* if so :)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Hah! Nope, those are the semi-soft, aged chevre. But feel free to go all
Fernand Point on it if you want. ("Butter, give me butter, always butter!").

comments.author: Vegetarian Perspective
comments.content: Man, you are always giving me ideas! I love the roasted tomato concept, and since it feels like Fall here in MN, a great way to warm the house!

comments.author: arugulove
comments.content: This looks really lovely.  I've never really properly roasted tomatoes, so I'm excited to try!  My farmers market has some spectacular tomatoes - almost too beautiful to make sauce, but I love the idea of roasting them.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Thanks! Yeah, I wouldn't probably use perfect $6/lb heirlooms for roasting -
this is more of the place to use the #2s they might be selling for cheap, or
some that a neighbor gives you that are a little underripe - a fantastic way
to take some tomatoes that are a bit less than perfect and turn them into a
true treat.

comments.author: Jessica
comments.content: This looks delicious!  I've made risotto several times, but I've always included some sort of seafood or meat.  I'm eager to try it your way!

comments.author: Boracay hotel accommodation
comments.content: I've been thinking about cooking rissoto these past few days. This one looks perfect. Thank you for your wonderful recipe. God bless!

comments.author: arugulove
comments.content:
Actually, at my local farmers market, heirlooms are $2/pound.  Lucky me!

I'm wondering if there might be another reason to stay away from them...are they too watery?  I know romas are generally firmer.  Thoughts?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I don't have any experience oven roasting heirlooms, but I think it should be fine, just allow a bit more time. It looks like my old pal Bri has had success: http://figswithbri.com/?p=22

comments.author: Alana
comments.content: I made it -- wonderful, and so seasonal!  I also loved not having to prepare or buy broth. My boyfriend now calls it "haute mac n cheese". THANK YOU!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
So glad you liked it, and thanks for letting me know! That always makes my
day.

comments.author: oddjob
comments.content: If you can find it "Drunken Goat" is a lovely aged Spanish goat cheese that I think would work nicely with this risotto.  The cheese is so named because at some point during the aging the process the cheese gets a dunk in red wine, which colors and flavors the surface of the cheese in a nice way.

comments.author: SFO
comments.content: Another fantastic recipe, thanks!  I used Campari tomoatoes and got only a few teaspoons of "water" and ran out of arborio so used short grain brown, but it was still fantastic.
